arch:property.oc:show_val: This deposit is a Munsell Reddish Yellow 7.5YR 6/6. It is comprised of sand mixed with small amounts of stucco and pottery. Elements of collapsed arch wall and column drums are also present. The distribution of these materials appears to be random in nature.
Phase XII: Robbing and abandonment continue.
Phase XI: Further collapse post-CE 5th c. Possibly the result of the earthquake of CE 512.
All the architectural loci in the center and south trenchLoci 2, 3, 4, 6, and 7.
Closing elevation: + 0.50 m above Locus 10 Pavement or 893.05 m.
Loci 8 and 9 also soil and debris loci.

Phase IX: Major CE 363 earthquake leads to the collapse of the south gallery cryptoporticus of the Propylaeum West. The temple north colonnade falls from south to north across the Propylaeum, damage is incurred on the Propylaeum Retaining Wall and the entire area is overburdened with soil and debris.
Soil loci and debris of Trench 80 2001.
Throughout the original trench size 5.50 north south-by-6.70 east west to Sub datum 3, which originally was the north extent of the trench.
Phase XIII: Major collapses continue into the Islamic period.
Phase X: Site abandonment post major collapse dating to the Byzantine period from the CE 4th through 5th c.
Major accumulation of debris and topsoil following the collapse of the north colonnade.
Opening elevation: At 81/1  1.29 m, at SD 3  0.43 m.
